title: Erdős #750: Almost Bipartite Graphs with Infinite Chromatic Number

problemStatement.formal: \forall f: \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}, f(m) \to \infty \implies \exists G: \chi(G) = \infty \land (\forall S \subseteq V(G), |S|=m \implies \alpha(G[S]) \geq m/2 - f(m))
problemStatement.plain: Does there exist a graph G with infinite chromatic number such that every m-vertex subgraph has an independent set of size ≥ m/2 - f(m)?
whyMatters: Explores tension between local and global chromatic structure
Bipartite graphs achieve m/2 exactly - how close can we get?

proven: Erdős-Hajnal (1967): Holds for f(m) = cm where c > 1/4
Erdős-Hajnal-Szemerédi (1982): Holds for f(m) = εm for any ε > 0
open: Sublinear functions f(m) = o(m) with f(m) → ∞
Specific cases: f(m) = √m, f(m) = log m

currentState.focus: Full formalization with known results axiomatized. EHS82 linear case proved as corollary.
blockers: Problem is OPEN for sublinear functions
